subject: Re: [junit] testing switch statements in method
msgSnippet: ... It wasn t clear to me, but that could just be my fault for not reading carefully. In that case, I would look specifically at the subclass to test pattern
messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

> I think Kamal made it clear that changing the API was not an option, so he's
> definitely looking for an option to test an API that he has no control
> over. Sad, but fairly common in my opinion.

It wasn't clear to me, but that could just be my fault for not reading
carefully.

In that case, I would look specifically at the "subclass to test"
pattern in _Working Effectively with Legacy Code_. It doesn't help with
private methods, but it does help with protected ones.

For private methods, invoke the method by reflection, changing the
accessibility. There should be a recipe in _JUnit Recipes_ about it. The
title is, if I remember, "Test private methods if you must".

> I envy people who have write access to 100% of the code they need to test,
> they don't know how easy they have it :-)

This is an arrogant statement, but it's true. I apologize for that.

I pity people who stay in a job where they don't have write access to
the code they need to test. They don't seem to realize how crazy that is.
